page.title: 02SW.Cheshire:Soils & Water.
page.content: Rising from under 30 metres to just over 40 metres the area consists largely of a ridge which has{very} gentle gradients.The more gentle west facing slope is dissectd by a number of valleys with small streams in them. Some parts of their channels have been alterred & with hedges form field boundaries.Clay (& some sandstone) covers large parts & has been dug out, on a small scale,in the past,for the making of bricks for some of the farm buildings.There are therefore,a great many small ponds scattered around,some being natural as it is lowland & the water-table is close to the surface and others being small shallow,flooded workings.Many small marshy areas also occur in the impervious clay. By Platt's Lane there is also a larger very shallow pond with reeds growing to a height of 150 centimetres or so.
